articles.headline: With a Cellphone as My Guide
articles.snippet: A new service in Japan allows users to point a cellphone at a location of interest and the phone will display information describing what they are looking at.
articles.abstract: A new service in Japan allows users to point a cellphone at a location of interest and the phone will display information describing what they are looking at.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think of it as a divining rod for the information age.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Daimler Hopes Americans Are Finally Ready for the Minicar
articles.snippet: The carmaker is betting that with high gasoline prices and concerns about global warming consumers will welcome the tiny two-seat vehicle.
articles.abstract: The carmaker is betting that with high gasoline prices and concerns about global warming consumers will welcome the tiny two-seat vehicle.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, June 27 — Are Americans finally ready to get Smart?

articles.headline: Univision Jilts Televisa for Rival Bid
articles.snippet: It's a plot from a telenovela that might be seen on Univision: a months-long courtship with a surprise twist and a jilted groom, hinting at revenge.
articles.abstract: It's a plot from a telenovela that might be seen on Univision: a months-long courtship with a surprise twist and a jilted groom, hinting at revenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a plot from a telenovela that might be seen on Univision: A months-long courtship with a surprise twist and a jilted groom, hinting at revenge.

articles.headline: U.S. Tactic on KPMG Questioned
articles.snippet: A federal judge ruled that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees.
articles.abstract: A federal judge ruled that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled yesterday that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees, a decision that may change the way the government pursues white-collar cases.

articles.headline: Push for New Tactics as War on Malaria Falters
articles.snippet: After years of failed efforts to fight malaria, major donors are increasing financing and pushing for a new approach.
articles.abstract: After years of failed efforts to fight malaria, major donors are increasing financing and pushing for a new approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mosquito nets arrived too late for 18-month-old Phillip Odong.

articles.headline: Charities Tied to Doctors Get Drug Industry Gifts
articles.snippet: Critics say the payments can bias the doctors' treatment decisions and may lead to suspect research findings.
articles.abstract: Critics say the payments can bias the doctors' treatment decisions and may lead to suspect research findings.
articles.lead_paragraph: As she presented research results indicating that a new medical device was "an important breakthrough," the doctor's enthusiasm was clear. Less evident were some of the financial links between the researchers and the device's maker.

articles.headline: How To Give Money as Buffett Does
articles.snippet: When the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation came out, I figured there must be something that I was missing.
articles.abstract: When the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation came out, I figured there must be something that I was missing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation started coming out the other night, I figured there must be something that I was missing. He's giving away $31 billion, and he's not getting a single thing named for himself?

articles.headline: Israeli Troops Move Into Gaza; Bridges Are Hit
articles.snippet: Israel sent troops into Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday in an operation to rescue a soldier abducted by militants.
articles.abstract: Israel sent troops into Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday in an operation to rescue a soldier abducted by militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Wednesday, June 28 — Israel sent troops into southern Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday, in an effort to prevent militants from moving a wounded Israeli soldier they abducted Sunday, Israeli Army officials said.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Anglican Plan Threatens Split on Gay Issues
articles.snippet: The Episcopal Church in the United States could be forced  to give up full membership in the Anglican Communion.
articles.abstract: The Episcopal Church in the United States could be forced  to give up full membership in the Anglican Communion.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a defining moment in the Anglican Communion's civil war over homosexuality, the Archbishop of Canterbury proposed a plan yesterday that could force the Episcopal Church in the United States either to renounce gay bishops and same-sex unions or to give up full membership in the Communion.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Neela Banerjee

articles.headline: Univision Jilts Televisa for Rival Bid
articles.snippet: It is a plot from a telenovela that might be seen on Univision: A months-long courtship with a surprise twist and a jilted groom, hinting at revenge.      That was the scene yesterday after a consortium of private equity firms won an auction for U...
articles.abstract: It is a plot from a telenovela that might be seen on Univision: A months-long courtship with a surprise twist and a jilted groom, hinting at revenge.      That was the scene yesterday after a consortium of private equity firms won an auction for Univision Communications, the largest Spanish-language media company in the United States, with a $12.3 billion bid, prompting the rival suitor, Grupo Televisa, to contend it had been deliberately shunned in favor of a lesser bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a plot from a telenovela that might be seen on Univision: A months-long courtship with a surprise twist and a jilted groom, hinting at revenge.

articles.headline: Israeli Troops Move Into Gaza; Bridges Are Hit
articles.snippet: Israel sent troops into southern Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday, in an effort to prevent militants from moving a wounded Israeli soldier they abducted Sunday, Israeli Army officials said.     Israeli...
articles.abstract: Israel sent troops into southern Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday, in an effort to prevent militants from moving a wounded Israeli soldier they abducted Sunday, Israeli Army officials said.     Israeli troops and tanks began to move in force in an effort to rescue the soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, 19, who is believed to be held there.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Wednesday, June 28 - Israel sent troops into southern Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday, in an effort to prevent militants from moving a wounded Israeli soldier they abducted Sunday, Israeli Army officials said.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Anglican Plan Threatens Split on Gay Issues
articles.snippet: In a defining moment in the Anglican Communion's civil war over homosexuality, the Archbishop of Canterbury proposed a plan yesterday that could force the Episcopal Church in the United States either to renounce gay bishops and same-sex unions or ...
articles.abstract: In a defining moment in the Anglican Communion's civil war over homosexuality, the Archbishop of Canterbury proposed a plan yesterday that could force the Episcopal Church in the United States either to renounce gay bishops and same-sex unions or to give up full membership in the Communion.     The archbishop, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, said the ''best way forward'' was to devise a shared theological ''covenant'' and ask each province, as the geographical divisions of the church are called, to agree to abide by it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a defining moment in the Anglican Communion's civil war over homosexuality, the Archbishop of Canterbury proposed a plan yesterday that could force the Episcopal Church in the United States either to renounce gay bishops and same-sex unions or to give up full membership in the Communion.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Neela Banerjee

articles.headline: U.S. Tactic on KPMG Questioned
articles.snippet: A federal judge ruled yesterday that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees, a decision that may change the way the government pursues white-collar cases.      The ruling,...
articles.abstract: A federal judge ruled yesterday that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees, a decision that may change the way the government pursues white-collar cases.      The ruling, by Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of United States District Court in Manhattan, who is overseeing the trial of former employees of the accounting firm KPMG, is the first major criticism from the bench of tactics that federal prosecutors have adopted since a wave of corporate scandals erupted after the collapse of Enron.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled yesterday that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees, a decision that may change the way the government pursues white-collar cases.

articles.headline: Daimler Hopes Americans Are Finally Ready for the Minicar
articles.snippet: Are Americans finally ready to get Smart?     DaimlerChrysler, which shelved an earlier plan to bring its Smart minicar brand to the United States, plans to announce Wednesday that it will introduce the tiny two-seat vehicle to the American market...
articles.abstract: Are Americans finally ready to get Smart?     DaimlerChrysler, which shelved an earlier plan to bring its Smart minicar brand to the United States, plans to announce Wednesday that it will introduce the tiny two-seat vehicle to the American market early in 2008, according to several executives at the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, June 27 - Are Americans finally ready to get Smart?

articles.headline: How To Give Money as Buffett Does
articles.snippet: WHEN the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation started coming out the other night, I figured there must be something that I was missing. He's giving away $31 billion, and he's not getting a single thing nam...
articles.abstract: WHEN the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation started coming out the other night, I figured there must be something that I was missing. He's giving away $31 billion, and he's not getting a single thing named for himself?      Some people write a $10,000 check to their alma mater and expect to get a plaque celebrating their generosity, and here was Mr. Buffett making a gift that will effectively send $10,000 to the Gates Foundation every three minutes for decades on end. For that amount of money, he could have founded Buffett University in his native Nebraska with an endowment larger than Harvard's, or he could have set up the world's richest foundation -- the Buffett Foundation -- and engaged in a little competitive philanthropy with his fellow bridge player Mr. Gates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation started coming out the other night, I figured there must be something that I was missing. He's giving away $31 billion, and he's not getting a single thing named for himself?

articles.headline: With a Cellphone as My Guide
articles.snippet: Think of it as a divining rod for the information age.     If you stand on a street corner in Tokyo today you can point a specialized cellphone at a hotel, a restaurant or a historical monument, and with the press of a button the phone will displa...
articles.abstract: Think of it as a divining rod for the information age.     If you stand on a street corner in Tokyo today you can point a specialized cellphone at a hotel, a restaurant or a historical monument, and with the press of a button the phone will display information from the Internet describing the object you are looking at.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think of it as a divining rod for the information age.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Charities Tied to Doctors Get Drug Industry Gifts
articles.snippet: As she presented research results indicating that a new medical device was ''an important breakthrough,'' the doctor's enthusiasm was clear. Less evident were some of the financial links between the researchers and the device's maker.      Dr. Mar...
articles.abstract: As she presented research results indicating that a new medical device was ''an important breakthrough,'' the doctor's enthusiasm was clear. Less evident were some of the financial links between the researchers and the device's maker.      Dr. Maria Rosa Costanzo, making her presentation at a March conference of cardiologists, said the study found that a $14,000 blood filtering device was better than intravenous diuretic drugs at removing excess fluid from patients with heart failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: As she presented research results indicating that a new medical device was "an important breakthrough," the doctor's enthusiasm was clear. Less evident were some of the financial links between the researchers and the device's maker.

articles.headline: FLAG AMENDMENT NARROWLY FAILS IN SENATE VOTE
articles.snippet: A proposed Constitutional amendment to allow Congress to prohibit desecration of the flag fell a single vote short of approval by the Senate on Tuesday, an excruciatingly close vote that left unresolved a long-running debate over whether the flag ...
articles.abstract: A proposed Constitutional amendment to allow Congress to prohibit desecration of the flag fell a single vote short of approval by the Senate on Tuesday, an excruciatingly close vote that left unresolved a long-running debate over whether the flag is a unique national symbol deserving of special legal standing.     The 66-to-34 vote on the amendment was one vote short of the 67 required to send the amendment to the states for potential ratification as the 28th Amendment. It was the closest proponents of the initiative have come in four Senate votes since the Supreme Court first ruled in 1989 that flag burning was a protected form of free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 27 - A proposed Constitutional amendment to allow Congress to prohibit desecration of the flag fell a single vote short of approval by the Senate on Tuesday, an excruciatingly close vote that left unresolved a long-running debate over whether the flag is a unique national symbol deserving of special legal standing.
